{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Life timeline}}
The '''largest prehistoric organisms''' include both [[vertebrate]] and [[invertebrate]] species. Many are described below, along with their typical range of size (for the general dates of extinction, see the link to each). Many species mentioned might not actually be the largest representative of their clade due to the incompleteness of the [[fossil record]] and many of the sizes given are merely estimates since no complete specimen have been found. Their body mass, especially, is mostly conjecture because soft tissue was rarely fossilized. Generally the size of extinct species was subject to energetic<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Carbone | first1=Chris | last2=Teacher | first2=Amber | last3=Rowcliffe | first3=J |title=The Costs of Carnivory |journal=PLoS Biology |volume=5 |issue=2 |page=e22 |url=http://www.plosbiology.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pbio.0050022 |accessdate=2009-12-28 | doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.0050022 | year=2007 | pmid=17227145 | pmc=1769424}}</ref> and biomechanical constraints.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hokkanen|first=J.E.I. |date=21 February 1986|title=The size of the largest land animal|journal=Journal of Theoretical Biology|publisher=Elsevier Ltd|volume= 118| issue = 4|pages=491–499|doi=10.1016/S0022-5193(86)80167-9|pmid=3713220}} Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Helsinki.</ref>
== Vertebrates ==
=== Mammals ([[Mammalia]]) ===
==== Monotremes ([[Monotremata]]) ==== The largest-known [[monotreme]] (egg-laying mammal) ever was the extinct [[long-beaked echidna]] species known as ''[[Zaglossus hacketti]]'', known from a couple of bones found in Western Australia. It was the size of a sheep, weighing probably up to {{cvt|30|kg}}.<ref name="TourismWA">{{cite web |author=Staff |title =''Zaglossus hacketti'' – extinct giant echidna |url=http://www.megafauna.com.au/view/megafauna/zaglossus-hacketti |work=Tourism Western Australia |accessdate=2014-04-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126010215/http://www.megafauna.com.au/view/megafauna/zaglossus-hacketti |archivedate=2014-01-26}}</ref>
==== Even-toed ungulates ([[Artiodactyla]]) ==== [[File:Hippopotamus gorgops e.jpg|thumb|The extinct ''[[Hippopotamus gorgops]]'' is the most massive of the fossil even-toed ungulates.]] * The largest-known [[Artiodactyla|artiodactyl]] was ''[[Hippopotamus gorgops]]'' with a length of {{cvt|4.3|m}} and a height of {{cvt|2.1|m}}. ''[[Bison latifrons]]'' reached a shoulder height of {{cvt|2.5|m}}, and had horns that spanned over {{cvt|2|m}}. The largest extinct bovid is [[Aurochs]] (''Bos primigenius'') with an average height at the shoulders of {{cvt|155|-|180|cm}} in bulls and {{cvt|135|-|155|cm}} in cows, while aurochs populations in Hungary had bulls reaching {{cvt|155|–|160|cm}}.<ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Kysely | first1 = René | title = Aurochs and potential crossbreeding with domestic cattle in Central Europe in the Eneolithic period. A metric analysis of bones from the archaeological site of Kutná Hora-Denemark (Czech Republic) | url = | journal = Anthropozoologica | volume = 43 | issue = 2| page = 2008}}</ref> * The largest-known camel that ever lived was the [[Syrian camel]]. It was {{cvt|3|m}} at the shoulder and {{cvt|13|ft|order=flip}} tall. ''[[Gigantocamelus]]'' and ''[[Titanotylopus]]'' from North America, both possibly reached {{cvt|2485.6|kg}} and a shoulder height of over {{cvt|3.4|m}}.<ref>[http://www.intechinc.com/disappeared-species/giant-camel.html Giant Camel Disappeared Species] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110150125/http://www.intechinc.com/disappeared-species/giant-camel.html |date=2013-11-10 }}. Intechinc.com (2011-07-05)</ref><ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Mendoza| first1 = M. | last2 = Janis | first2 = C. M. | last3 = Palmqvist | first3 = P. | year = 2006 | title = Estimating the body mass of extinct ungulates: a study on the use of multiple regression | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-7998.2006.00094.x | journal = Journal of Zoology | volume = 270 | issue = 1| pages = 90–101}}</ref> * ''[[Daeodon]]'' was the largest-known [[entelodont]] that ever lived, at {{cvt|12|ft|order=flip}} long and {{cvt|7|ft|order=flip}} at the shoulder. The largest-known wild suid to ever exist was ''[[Kubanochoerus|Kubanochoerus gigas]]'', having measured up to {{cvt|550|kg}} and stood more than {{cvt|1.3|m}} tall at the shoulder.<ref>[http://www.tesorosnaturales.es/en/catalogo.php?categoria=9&producto=141 Teeth: Kubanochoerus gigas lii (GUAN)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. tesorosnaturales.es</ref> * The extinct [[Irish elk]] (''Megaloceros giganteus'') and the [[stag-moose]] (''Cervalces scotti'') were of similar size to the Alaskan moose. However, the Irish elk could have antlers spanning up to {{cvt|4.3|m}} across, about twice the maximum span for a moose's antlers.<ref>David Petersen. [http://www.motherearthnews.com/Nature-Community/1989-03-01/Of-Moose-Megaloceros-and-Miracles.aspx Of Moose, Megaloceros and Miracles]. Motherearthnews.com (1989-03-01)</ref> ''[[Cervalces latifrons]]'' was twice as heavy as the Irish elk but its antlers were smaller.<ref name=Geist>{{Cite journal|first = Valerius |last = Geist |title = ''Deer of the world: their evolution, behaviour, and ecology'' |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bcWZX-IMEVkC&pg=PA122&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4#v=onepage&q=Cervalces%20latifrons&f=false}}Oxworth Books. pp. 111, 126, 247–250. (1998) {{ISBN|0811704963}}</ref>
==== Marsupials ([[Marsupialia]]) ==== * The largest-known extinct [[marsupial]] was ''[[Diprotodon]]'', about {{cvt|3|m}} long, standing {{cvt|2|m}} tall and weighing up to {{cvt|2786|kg}}.<ref name="smh">[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/10/1016_031017_giantmarsupial.html Ice Age Marsupial Topped Three Tons, Scientists Say], 2003-09-17. Retrieved 2003-09-17.</ref> * The two largest-known carnivorous marsupials were the [[marsupial lion]] and ''[[Thylacosmilus]]'' (larger than the [[Tasmanian tiger]]), both about {{cvt|6|ft|order=flip}} long and weighing {{cvt|100|-|160|kg}}. The largest-known kangaroo ever was ''[[Procoptodon]]'', which could grow to {{cvt|10|ft|m|0|order=flip}} and weigh {{cvt|230|kg}}.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Helgen, K.M., Wells, R.T., Kear, B.P., Gerdtz, W.R., and Flannery, T.F. | year = 2006 | title = Ecological and evolutionary significance of sizes of giant extinct kangaroos | journal = Australian Journal of Zoology | volume=54 | pages=293–303 | doi = 10.1071/ZO05077}}</ref> Some species from the genus ''[[Sthenurus]]'' were similar in size as well. * The largest palorchestids ''[[Palorchestes]]'' was almost as large as a [[horse]], being around {{cvt|2.5|m}} in length with a weight of about {{cvt|200|kg}}, and had four powerful legs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/paleofilescom/palorchestes|title=Palorchestes – paleofiles.com|website=sites.google.com}}</ref>
==== Carnivores ([[Carnivora]]) ==== * The largest terrestrial known [[carnivora]]n and the largest-known [[bear]] as well as the largest-known mammalian land-predator of all time was ''[[Arctotherium angustidens]]'' or the South American short-faced bears. A [[humerus]] of ''A. angustidens'' from [[Buenos Aires]] indicate that the large males could have weighed {{cvt|1,588|-|1,749|kg}} and standing at least {{cvt|11|ft|order=flip}} tall on the hind-limbs.<ref name="Soibelzon2">{{Cite journal | last = Soibelzon | first = L. H. | authorlink = |author2=Schubert, B. W. | title = The Largest Known Bear, ''Arctotherium angustidens'', from the Early Pleistocene Pampean Region of Argentina: With a Discussion of Size and Diet Trends in Bears | journal = [[Journal of Paleontology]] | volume = 85 | issue = 1 | pages = 69–75 | publisher = [[Paleontological Society]] | date = January 2011 | url = http://jpaleontol.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/85/1/69 | doi = 10.1666/10-037.1 | accessdate = 2011-06-01}}</ref><ref>Dell'Amore, C. (2011): [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2011/02/110203-biggest-bear-largest-giant-short-faced-animals-science/ Biggest Bear Ever Found], [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] News, Published February 3, 2011</ref> * The largest [[viverrid]] known to have existed is ''[[Viverra leakeyi]]'', which was around the size of a [[wolf]] or [[Amur leopard|small leopard]] at {{cvt|41|kg}}.<ref>Alan Turner, ''National Geographic Prehistoric Mammals'' National Geographic, 2004, {{ISBN|0792271343}}</ref> * The heaviest known [[felid]]s are the [[Panthera tigris soloensis|Ngangdong tiger]] (''Panthera tigris soloensis''), with the largest specimen weighing up to {{cvt|470|kg}} <ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S003101820700466X |doi=10.1016/j.palaeo.2007.09.004 |volume=257 |title=Assessing prey competition in fossil carnivore communities — a scenario for prey competition and its evolutionary consequences for tigers in Pleistocene Java |journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology |pages=67–80}}</ref><ref name="Quaternary extinctions">{{cite book|author= Paul S Martin|title= Quaternary Extinctions |publisher=The University of Arizona Press |year=1984 |ISBN=0-8165-1100-4}}</ref>, the [[American lion]] (''Panthera leo atrox'' or ''P. atrox''), weighing up to {{cvt|420|kg}}<ref name="MerriamStock1932">[[John Campbell Merriam|Merriam, J. C.]] & Stock, C. 1932: The Felidae of Rancho La Brea. Carnegie Institution of Washington Publications 442, 1–231.</ref><ref name="DeSantisetal.,2012">{{cite journal |author1=DeSantis, L. R. |author2=Schubert, B. W. |author3=Scott, J. R. |author4=Ungar, P. S. |title=Implications of diet for the extinction of saber-toothed cats and American lions |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=12 |pages=e52453 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0052453 |pmid=23300674 |pmc=3530457 |year=2012 |bibcode=2012PLoSO...752453D}}</ref> and [[saber-toothed cat]]s ''[[Amphimachairodus|Amphimachairodus kabir]]'' and ''[[Smilodon|Smilodon populator]]'', with the males possibly reaching {{cvt|350|-|490|kg}} and {{cvt|220|-|400|kg}} respectively.<ref name=Sorkin /> <ref name="Peignéde2005">{{cite journal |last1=Peigné |first1=S. |last2=de Bonis |first2=L. |last3=Likius |first3=A. |last4=Mackaye |first4=H. T. |last5=Vignaud |first5=P. |last6=Brunet |first6=M. |title=A new machairodontine (Carnivora, Felidae) from the Late Miocene hominid locality of TM 266, Toros-Menalla, Chad |journal=Comptes Rendus Palevol |volume=4 |issue=3 |year=2005 |pages=243–253 |doi=10.1016/j.crpv.2004.10.002}}</ref> * The largest known wolf species is the [[dire wolf]] (''Canis dirus'') {{cvt|1.5|m}} in length and weighed between {{cvt|50|and|110|kg|lb|sigfig=3}}.<ref name="Sorkin" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museum.state.il.us/exhibits/larson/canis.html|title=Wolves, Coyotes, and Dogs (Genus Canis)|publisher=Museum.state.il.us |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref> The largest [[canid]] of all time was ''[[Epicyon haydeni]]'', which stood {{cvt|37|in|m|order=flip}} tall at the shoulder. The largest [[bear-dog]] was a species of ''[[Pseudocyon]]'' weighing around {{cvt|773|kg}}, representing a very large individual.<ref>http://www.app.pan.pl/archive/published/app56/app20100005.pdf</ref> * The largest-known [[mustelid]] to ever exist was likely the giant otter, ''[[Enhydriodon]]''. It exceeded {{cvt|3|m}} in length, and would have weighed in at around {{cvt|200|kg}}, much larger than any other known mustelid, living or extinct.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1080/02724634.2011.550356 | volume=31 | title=Enhydriodon dikikae, sp. nov. (Carnivora: Mammalia), a gigantic otter from the Pliocene of Dikika, Lower Awash, Ethiopia | journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology | pages=447–453}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2011/03/the-bear-otter/|title=The Bear Otter|website=wired.com}}</ref> There were other giant otters, like ''[[Siamogale]]'', at around {{cvt|50|kg}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sci-news.com/paleontology/siamogale-melilutra-giant-otter-04557.html|title=Siamogale melilutra: Giant Otter Fossils Reveal New Species – Paleontology – Sci-News.com|website=sci-news.com}}</ref> and ''[[Megalenhydris]]'', which was larger than a modern-day giant river otter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scienceblogs.com/tetrapodzoology/2007/12/20/island-endemic-otters-canids/|title=Islands of otters and strange foxes|website=scienceblogs.com}}</ref> Another large-bodied mustelid was the superficially cat-like ''[[Ekorus]]'' from Africa, about the size of a [[leopard]] and filling a similar ecological niche before big cats came to the continent. ''[[Megalictis]]'' was thought to be around the size of a black bear according to old estimates. Newer estimates, however, significantly downgrade its size, although, at a maximum weight more than twice that of a wolverine, it is larger than most (if not all) living mustelids. * The largest known fossil hyena is ''[[Pachycrocuta]]'', estimated at {{cvt|190|kg}}.<ref name="Sorkin">{{cite journal | last1=Sorkin | first1=B | year=2008 | title=A biomechanical constraint on body mass in terrestrial mammalian predators | url= | journal=Lethaia | volume=41 | issue= | pages=333–347 | doi=10.1111/j.1502-3931.2007.00091.x}}</ref> The closely related [[Percrocutidae|percrocutid]] feliform, ''[[Dinocrocuta]]'', was even bigger, {{cvt|300|kg}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://chasingsabretooths.wordpress.com/2016/01/12/sabertooths-bane-introducing-dinocrocuta/|title=SABERTOOTH’S BANE: INTRODUCING DINOCROCUTA|date=12 January 2016|website=wordpress.com}}</ref>
==== Armadillos, glyptodonts and pampatheres ([[Cingulata]]) ==== The largest [[Cingulata|cingulate]] known is ''[[Doedicurus]]'', at {{cvt|3.8|m}} long and reaching a mass of approximately {{cvt|1910|to|2370|kg|ST}} ''[[Glyptodon]]'' easily topped {{cvt|3.3|m}} and {{cvt|2|tonne|ST}}.
==== Hedgehogs, gymnures, shrews, and moles ([[Erinaceomorpha]] and [[Soricomorpha]]) ==== The largest-known animal of this group was ''[[Deinogalerix]]'',<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Villier | first1 = Boris | year = 2010 | title = Deinogalerix: a giant hedgehog from the Miocene | journal = Annali dell’Università di Ferrara | volume=6| pages=93–102 |ISSN = 1824-2707}}</ref> measuring up to {{cvt|60|cm}} in total length, with a skull up to {{cvt|20|cm}} long. It occupied the same ecological niche as dogs and cats today.
==== Rabbits, hares, and pikas ([[Lagomorpha]]) ==== The largest-known prehistoric lagomorph is [[Minorcan giant lagomorph]] (''Nuralagus rex'') at {{cvt|23|kg}}. [[File:Indricotherium11.jpg|thumb|One of the largest land mammals of all time was [[Paraceratherium]]]]
==== Cimolestids ([[Cimolesta]]) ==== The largest-known [[cimolestes|cimolestid]] is ''[[Coryphodon]]'', {{cvt|1|m}} high at the shoulder and {{cvt|2.25|m}} long.
==== Odd-toed ungulates ([[Perissodactyla]]) ==== * The largest-known [[Perissodactyla|perissodactyl]], and the second largest land mammal (see ''[[Palaeoloxodon namadicus]]'') of all time was ''[[Paraceratherium]]''. The largest individual known was estimated at {{cvt|4.8|m|1}} tall at the shoulders, {{cvt|7.4|m|1}} in length from nose to rump, and {{cvt|17|tonne|ST|1}} in weight.<ref name="probos_mass">{{Cite journal | last1 = Larramendi | first1 = A. | last2 = | first2 = | year = 2016 | title = Shoulder height, body mass and shape of proboscideans | journal = Acta Palaeontologica Polonica | volume = 61 | issue = | pages = | publisher = | jstor = | doi = 10.4202/app.00136.2014 | url = https://www.app.pan.pl/archive/published/app61/app001362014.pdf | format = | accessdate =}}</ref><ref name="Fortelius">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1096-3642.1993.tb02560.x| title = The largest land mammal ever imagined| journal = Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society| volume = 108| pages = 85–101| year = 1993| last1 = Fortelius | first1 = M. | last2 = Kappelman | first2 = J. }}</ref> * Some prehistoric horned [[Rhinoceros|rhinos]] also grew to large sizes. The giant woolly rhino ''[[Elasmotherium]]'' reached {{cvt|6|m}} long and {{cvt|2|m}} high. The largest prehistoric horse was ''[[Equus giganteus]]'' of North America. It was estimated to grow to more than {{cvt|1250|kg|ST}} and {{cvt|2|m}} at the shoulders.<ref>http://www.vera-eisenmann.com/IMG/pdf/136.Gigantic_horses.pdf</ref>
==== Anteaters and sloths ([[Pilosa]]) ==== * The largest-known [[pilosa]]n ever was ''[[Megatherium]]'', a ground sloth with an estimated average weight of {{cvt|3.8|tonne|ST}}<ref name="web.archive.org">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/wildfacts/factfiles/456.shtml|title=BBC – Science & Nature – Wildfacts – Megatherium|date=2014-02-01|access-date=2017-06-29|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201215430/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/wildfacts/factfiles/456.shtml|archivedate=2014-02-01|df=}}</ref> and a height of {{cvt|6|m}}<ref name="web.archive.org" /> which is close to the size of the [[African bush elephant]]. Several other sloths grew to large sizes as well, such as ''[[Eremotherium]]'', but none as large as ''Megatherium''.
==== Primates ([[Primates]]) ==== * The largest-known [[primate]] of all time was ''[[Gigantopithecus blackii]]'', standing {{cvt|3|m}} tall and weighing {{cvt|1,200|lb|kg|order=flip}}.<ref name="ApeThatWas">{{cite web|last=Ciochon |first=Russell L |title=The Ape that Was – Asian fossils reveal humanity's giant cousin |url=http://www.uiowa.edu/%7Ebioanth/giganto.html |publisher=University of Iowa |accessdate=2007-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525202625/http://www.uiowa.edu/~bioanth/giganto.html |archivedate=2015-05-25 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Pettifor">{{cite book | last=Pettifor | first=Eric | title=Selected Readings in Physical Anthropology | chapter=From the Teeth of the Dragon: ''Gigantopithecus Blacki''| pages=143–149 | url=http://www.wynja.com/arch/gigantopithecus.html | year=2000 | origyear=1995 | publisher=Kendall/Hunt Publishing Company | isbn=0-7872-7155-1 | accessdate=2008-01-30}}</ref> * The largest-known old world monkey, the prehistoric baboon ''[[Dinopithecus]]'' grew even larger than modern Mandrills, weighing as much as a grown man. * Some prehistoric prosimians grew to huge sizes as well. ''[[Archaeoindris]]'' was a {{convert|1.5|m|ft|adj=mid|-long}} [[lemur]] that lived in [[Madagascar]] and weighed {{cvt|200|kg}}, as large as a silverback [[gorilla]]. ''[[Megaladapis]]'' is another large extinct lemur at {{cvt|1.3|to|1.5|m}} in length.
[[File:Hauerelefant-Deinotherium.jpg|thumb|Mounted ''[[Deinotherium]]'' skeleton]]
==== Elephants, mammoths, and mastodons ([[Proboscidea]]) ==== * The largest-known land mammal ever was a proboscidean called ''[[Palaeoloxodon namadicus]]'' which weighed about {{cvt|22|t|ST|1}}, and was about {{cvt|5.2|m|1}} tall at the shoulder.<ref name="probos_mass" /> The largest individuals of the [[steppe mammoth]] of [[Eurasia]] (''Mammuthus trogontherii'') estimated to reach {{cvt|4.5|m|1}} at the shoulders and {{cvt|14.3|t|ST}} in weight.<ref name="probos_mass"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Osborn|first=H. F.|title=Proboscidea, Vol. II|year=1942|publisher=The American Museum Press.|location=New York}}</ref> * Some other enormous proboscideans include the [[southern mammoth]] (''Mammuthus meridionalis''), the [[Columbian mammoth]] (''Mammuthus columbi''),{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} and ''[[Deinotherium]]''.
==== Rodents ([[Rodent]]ia) ==== * ''[[Josephoartigasia monesi]]'' was the largest-known [[rodent]] of all time, approximately {{cvt|3|m}} long and {{cvt|1.5|m}} tall and weighing an estimated {{cvt|1|tonne|ST}}.<ref name="Rinderknecht">{{cite journal| laysummary = http://journals.royalsociety.org/content/34j867846u164624/| title = The largest fossil rodent | doi = 10.1098/rspb.2007.1645 | url = http://journals.royalsociety.org/content/34j867846u164624/fulltext.pdf | format = pdf | last = Rinderknecht | first = Andrés |author2=R. Ernesto Blanco | date = 2008-01-15 | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences | accessdate = 2008-01-16 | volume = 275 | pages = 923–8 | pmid = 18198140 | issue = 1637 | pmc = 2599941}}</ref> * Before the discovery of ''Josephoartigasia monesi'', another giant rodent was known, ''[[Phoberomys insolita]]'', but it was known from only a few fragments, so its real size is unknown. A slightly smaller relative, ''[[Phoberomys pattersoni]]'', was found, which was {{cvt|3|m}} long and weighed {{cvt|700|lb|order=flip}}. * The largest beaver was the [[Castoroides|giant beaver]] of North America. It grew over {{cvt|8|ft|order=flip}} in length and weighed roughly {{cvt|60|to|100|kg}}, also making it one of the largest rodents to ever exist.
==== Astrapotherians ([[Astrapotheria]]) ==== The largest-known astrapotherians weighed about {{cvt|3-4|tonne|ST}}, including the genus ''[[Granastrapotherium]]''<ref>Johnson, Steven C. & Madden, Richard H. 1997. Uruguaytheriinae Astrapotheres of Tropical South America. Chapter 22 in "Vertebrate Paleontology in the Neotropics. The Miocene Fauna of La Venta, Colombia". Edited by Richard F. Kay, Richard H. Madden, Richard L. Cifelli, and John J. Flynn. Smithsonian Institution Press. Washington and London.</ref> and some species of ''[[Parastrapotherium]]'' (''P. martiale'').<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Kramarz | first1 = Alejandro G. | last2 = Bond | first2 = Mariano | title = Revision of ''Parastrapotherium'' (Mammalia, Astrapotheria) and other Deseadan astrapotheres of Patagonia | year = 2008 | journal = Ameghiniana | volume = 45 | issue = 3 | url = http://www.scielo.org.ar/scielo.php?pid=S0002-70142008000300003&script=sci_arttext | accessdate = March 1, 2013 | ref = harv}}</ref>
==== Arsinoitheres ([[Arsinoitheriidae]]) ==== The largest-known [[arsinoithere]] was ''[[Arsinoitherium]]''. When alive, it would have been {{cvt|1.8|m}} tall at the shoulders, and {{cvt|3|m}} long.
==== Condylarths ([[Condylarthra]]) ==== The largest-known condylarth is ''[[Phenacodus]]''. It was {{cvt|1.5|m}} long and weighted up to {{cvt|56|kg}}.
==== Dinoceratans ([[Dinocerata]]) ==== The largest-known [[dinocerata]]n was ''[[Uintatherium]]''. It was about the size of a [[rhinoceros]]. Despite its large size, it had a brain only about as large as an [[Orange (fruit)|orange]].
==== Desmostylians ([[Desmostylia]]) ==== The largest-known [[desmostylia]]n was a species comparable in size to the [[Steller's Sea Cow]].<ref>Nicholas D. Pyenson, Geerat J. Vermeij, The rise of ocean giants: maximum body size in Cenozoic marine mammals as an indicator for productivity in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, Published 5 July 2016.DOI: 10.1098/rsbl.2016.0186</ref>
==== Litopterns ([[Litopterna]]) ==== The largest-known [[Litopterna|litoptern]] was ''[[Macrauchenia]]'', which had three hoofs per foot. It was a relatively large animal, with a body length of around {{cvt|3|m}}.<ref name="Gingerich 1998">{{Cite book | last = Gingerich | first = Philip D. | author-link = Philip D. Gingerich | year = 1998 | contribution = Paleobiological Perspectives on Mesonychia, Archaeoceti, and the Origin of Whales | editor-last = Thewissen | editor-first = J.G.M. | title = The emergence of whales: evolutionary patterns in the origin of Cetacea | volume= | pages=423–450 | publisher = Plenum Press | place=New York | contribution-url= | isbn=978-0-306-45853-8 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref>
==== Notoungulates ([[Notoungulata]]) ==== [[File:SarkastodonDB.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Sarkastodon]]'']]
The largest [[Notoungulata|notoungulate]] known of complete remains is ''[[Toxodon]]''. It was about {{cvt|2.7|m}} in body length, and about {{cvt|1.5|m}} high at the shoulder and resembled a heavy rhinoceros. Although is not complete, the preserved fossils suggests that ''[[Mixotoxodon]]'' were the most massive member of the group, with a weight about {{cvt|3.8|tonne|ST}}.<ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Elissamburu | first1 = A | year = 2012 | title = Estimación de la masa corporal en géneros del Orden Notoungulata | url = http://estudiosgeol.revistas.csic.es/index.php/estudiosgeol/article/view/823 | journal = Estudios Geológicos | volume = 68 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.3989/egeol.40336.133 | pages=91–111}}</ref>
==== Oxyaenids ([[Oxyaenidae]]) ==== The largest-known [[Oxyaenidae|oxyaenid]] was ''[[Sarkastodon]]'' weighing in at {{cvt|800|kg}}.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sorkin | first1 = B. | year = 2008 | title = A biomechanical constraint on body mass in terrestrial mammalian predators | url = | journal = Lethaia | volume = 41 | issue = | pages = 333–347 | doi=10.1111/j.1502-3931.2007.00091.x}}</ref>
==== Hyaenodontids ([[Hyaenodontidae]]) ==== The largest [[Hyaenodontidae|hyaenodontid]] was ''[[Megistotherium]]'' at 500 kg.<ref name="Sorkin" />
==== Mesonychids ([[Mesonychia]]) ==== The largest [[mesonychid]] was ''[[Mongolonyx|Mongolonyx robustus]]''. This predator would have been {{cvt|1.3|-|1.4|m}} tall at the shoulders and {{cvt|2.7|-|2.8|m}} long.
===Non-mammal synapsids ([[Synapsida]])=== [[File:Anteosaurus in landscape.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Anteosaurus]]'' overviewing the landscape]]
===Pelycosaurs=== The herbivorous ''[[Cotylorhynchus|Cotylorhynchus hancocki]]'' was the largest of the [[pelycosaur]]s, with an estimated length and weight of at least {{cvt|6|m|0}} and {{cvt|500|kg}}.<ref>[http://permian.stratigraphy.org/files/20180825094514307.pdf. Permian Stratigraphy - International Commission on Stratigraphy International Union of Geological Sciences]</ref><ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3989228/ The Oldest Caseid Synapsid from the Late Pennsylvanian of Kansas, and the Evolution of Herbivory in Terrestrial Vertebrates - NCBI - NIH]</ref> The biggest carnivorous pelycosaur was ''[[Dimetrodon| Dimetrodon angelensis]]'', which could reach {{cvt|4.6|m|0}} and {{cvt|250|kg}}. The largest members of the genus Dimetrodon was also the world's first fully terrestrial [[apex predator]]s.<ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24509889 Hidden dental diversity in the oldest terrestrial apex predator Dimetrodon - NCBI]</ref>
===Therapsids=== The plant-eating [[dicynodont]] ''[[Lisowicia|Lisowicia bojani]]'' is the largest-known of all non-mammal [[Synapsida|synapsids]], at {{cvt|4.5|m}} and {{cvt|9000|kg}}.<ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/11/181123134400.htm Gigantic mammal 'cousin' discovered -- ScienceDaily]</ref> Among the largest carnivorous synapsids was the [[therapsid]] ''[[Anteosaurus]]'', which was {{cvt|5|-|6|m}} long, and weighed {{cvt|500|-|600|kg}}.<ref>van Valkenburgh, Blaire; Jenkins, Ian (2002). "Evolutionary Patterns in the History of Permo-Triassic and Cenozoic synapsid predators". Paleontological Society Papers 8: 267–288.</ref><ref name=Kheper>{{cite web|title=Brithopodidae / Anteosauridae|url=http://www.kheper.net/evolution/therapsida/Brithopodidae.html|website=Kheper|publisher=M.Alan Kazlev|accessdate=24 October 2015}}</ref>
=== Reptiles ([[Reptilia]]) === [[File:Varanus priscus Melbourne Museum.jpg|thumb|right|[[Megalania]] skeletal reconstruction on Melbourne Museum steps]]
==== Crocodiles and relatives ([[Crocodylomorpha]]) ==== * The largest-known crocodylomorph is likely ''[[Sarcosuchus imperator]]'' at {{cvt|12|m|0}} long and weighing {{cvt|8|tonne|ST}}.<ref name="SuperCrocFactSheet">{{cite web|url=http://www.supercroc.org/about.htm|title=Fact Sheet |accessdate=2007-09-22 |last=Lyon |first=Gabrielle |work=SuperCroc |publisher=Project Exploration}}</ref> * Some close contenders in size are ''[[Deinosuchus]]'' estimated at around {{cvt|12|m|0}},<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lucas|first=Spencer G. |author2=Robert M. Sullivan |author3=Justin A. Spielmann |title=The Giant Crocodylian Deinosuchus from the Upper Cretaceous of the San Juan Basin, New Mexico |journal=New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science Bulletin |volume=35 |location=Mexico |year=2006 |url=http://www.nmnaturalhistory.org/science/bulletins/35/sci_bulletin35_29.pdf |accessdate=11 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617095747/http://www.nmnaturalhistory.org/science/bulletins/35/sci_bulletin35_29.pdf |archivedate=June 17, 2009}}</ref> and ''[[Purussaurus]]'' estimated at {{cvt|11|-|13|m|0}} in length.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.4072/rbp.2006.2.02| last = Bocquentin| first = Jean| last2 = Melo| first2 = Janira| title = ''Stupendemys souzai'' sp. nov (Pleurodira, Podocnemididae) from the Miocene-Pliocene of the Solimões Formation, Brazil| journal = Sociedade Brasileira de Paleontologia| volume = 9| issue = 2| pages = 187–192| year = 2006| url = http://www.sbpbrasil.org/revista/edicoes/9_2/RBP9-2-Jean.pdf?ref=Sex%C5%9Ehop.Com| postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> Another large crocodilian is ''[[Rhamphosuchus]]'', estimated at {{cvt|8|–|11|m|0}} in length.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Head |first=J. J. |year=2001 |title=Systematics and body size of the gigantic, enigmatic crocodyloid ''Rhamphosuchus crassidens'', and the faunal history of Siwalik Group (Miocene) crocodylians |journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology |volume=21 |issue=Supplement to No. 3 |pages=59A|doi=10.1080/02724634.2001.10010852 }}</ref> * The largest terrestrial ''[[sebecid]]'' crocodylomorph is ''[[Barinasuchus]]'', from the Miocene of South America, which reached {{cvt|9|m}} long. * The largest-known [[rauisuchian]] is [[Fasolasuchus|Fasolasuchus tenax]], which measured an estimated 8–10 metres. It is both the largest rauisuchian known to science, and the largest non-dinosaurian terrestrial predator ever discovered.
==== Lizards and snakes ([[Squamata]]) ==== * Giant [[mosasaurs]] are the largest-known animals within this group. The largest-known mosasaur is likely ''[[Mosasaurus|Mosasaurus hoffmanni]]'', estimated at {{cvt|17.6|m|0}} in length.<ref>{{Cite journal| last = Dortangs| first = Rudi W.|author2=Anne S. Schulp|author3=Eric W. A. Mulder |author4=John W.M. Jagt | title = A large new mosasaur from the Upper Cretaceous of The Netherlands| journal = Netherlands Journal of Geosciences| volume = 81| issue = 1| pages = 1–8| location = Netherlands| year = 2002| url = http://www.njgonline.nl/publish/articles/000197/article.pdf| accessdate = 11 May 2010}}</ref> Another giant mosasaur is ''[[Tylosaurus]]'', estimated at {{cvt|10|-|14|m|0}} in length.<ref>{{Cite web| last = Everhart| first = Mike| title = Research: Tylosaurus proriger – A new record of a large mosasaur from the Smoky Hill Chalk| url=http://www.oceansofkansas.com/page10.html| accessdate = 12 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| title = Fact File: Tylosaurus Proriger from National Geographic| url = http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/prehistoric/tylosaurus/| accessdate = 12 May 2010}}</ref> Another large mosasaur is ''[[Hainosaurus|Hainosaurus bernardi]]'' (could be synonymous to Tylosaurus). It was once estimated at {{cvt|17|and|15|m|0}} in length,<ref>Russell, D. A. 1967. Systematics and morphology of American mosasaurs (Reptilia, Sauria). Yale Univ. Bull 23:241. pp.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lingham-Soliar | first1 = T | year = 1998 | title = Unusual death of a Cretaceous giant | url = | journal = Lethaia | volume = 31 | issue = | pages = 308–310 | doi=10.1111/j.1502-3931.1998.tb00520.x}}</ref> but later estimates put it at around {{cvt|12.2|m}}.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lindgren | first1 = Johan | year = 2005 | title = The first record of ''Hainosaurus'' (Reptilia: Mosasauridae) from Sweden | url = | journal = Journal of Paleontology | volume = 79 | issue = 6| pages = 1157–1165 | doi=10.1666/0022-3360(2005)079[1157:tfrohr]2.0.co;2}}</ref> * The largest-known prehistoric snake is ''[[Titanoboa|Titanoboa cerrejonensis]]'', estimated at {{cvt|12.8|m}} in length and {{cvt|1135|kg}} in weight.<ref name="Titan">{{Cite journal| last = Head| first = Jason J. |display-authors=etal <!---| coauthors = Jonathan I. Bloch, Alexander K. Hastings, Jason R. Bourque, Edwin A. Cadena, Fabiany A. Herrera, P. David Polly and Carlos A. Jaramillo--->| title = Giant boid snake from the Palaeocene neotropics reveals hotter past equatorial temperatures| journal = Nature| volume = 457| issue = 7230| pages = 715–717| publisher = Macmillan Publishers Limited| location = Colombia| date = 5 February 2009| pmid = 19194448| url = http://mkatti-classes.pbworks.com/f/Head_etal_GiantBoidSnake_Nature2009.pdf| doi = 10.1038/nature07671| accessdate = 12 May 2010| bibcode = 2009Natur.457..715H}}</ref> Another known very large fossil snake is ''[[Gigantophis|Gigantophis garstini]]'', estimated at around {{cvt|9.3|–|10.7|m|0}} in length.<ref>Head, J. & Polly, D. 2004. They might be giants: morphometric methods for reconstructing body size in the world’s largest snakes. ''Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology'' 24 (Supp. 3), 68A-69A.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg18424732-500-a-giant-among-snakes/|title=A giant among snakes|website=newscientist.com}}</ref> A close rival in size to ''Gigantophis'' is a fossil snake, ''[[Palaeophis|Palaeophis colossaeus]]'', which may have been around {{cvt|9|m|0}} in length.<ref name="Titan" /><ref>{{Cite journal| last = Rage| first = Jean-Claude|author2=Sunil Bajpai|author3=Johannes G. M. Thewissen |author4=Brahma N. Tiwari | title = Early Eocene snakes from Kutch, Western India, with a review of the Palaeophiidae| journal = Geodiversitas| volume = 25| issue = 4| pages = 695–716| publisher = Editions scientifiques du Muséum, Paris | location = India| year = 2003| url = http://www.mnhn.fr/publication/geodiv/g03n4a6.pdf| issn = 1280-9659| accessdate = 12 May 2010}}</ref><ref name=Rage1983>{{cite journal|last=Rage|first=J.-C.|title=''Palaeophis colossaeus'' nov. sp. (le plus grand Seprent connu?) de l’Eocène du Mali et le problème du genre chez les Palaeopheinae|journal=Comptes Rendus des Séances de l'Académie des Sciences |location=Paris |date=1983|volume=3|issue=296|pages=1741–1744}}</ref> * The largest-known land lizard is probably ''[[Megalania]]'' at {{cvt|7|m|0}} in length.<ref name=Molnar2004B>{{cite book|author=Molnar, Ralph E. |title=Dragons in the dust: the paleobiology of the giant monitor lizard Megalania |publisher=Indiana University Press |location=Bloomington |year=2004 |pages= |isbn=0-253-34374-7 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> However, maximum size of this animal is subject to debate.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Review of DRAGONS IN THE DUST: THE PALEOBIOLOGY OF THE GIANT MONITOR LIZARD ''MEGALANIA'', by Ralph E. Molnar, 2004 in the Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology 25(2):479, June 2005|url=http://socrates.berkeley.edu/~irmisr/megalania.pdf|accessdate=12 January 2012}}</ref>
==== [[Plesiosaurs]] ==== {{Main|Plesiosaur size}}
===== Plesiosauroids ([[Plesiosauroidea]]) ===== The longest known plesiosauroid was ''[[Styxosaurus]]'' at {{cvt|12|m}} long. Other elasmosaurs, such as ''[[Albertonectes]]'' and ''[[Thalassomedon]]'', rivaled the aforementioned ''[[Styxosaurus]]'' in size.
===== Pliosauroids ([[Pliosauroidea]]) ===== There is much controversy over the largest-known of these reptiles. Fossil remains of a pliosaur nicknamed as ''[[Predator X]]'' have been discovered and excavated from [[Norway]] in 2008. This pliosaur has been estimated at {{cvt|15|m|0}} in length and {{cvt|45|tonne|ST|0}} in weight.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/scienceandtechnology/5002074/Biggest-and-smallest-prehistoric-predators-unearthed.html |title=Biggest and smallest prehistoric predators unearthed |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |date=2009-03-17 |accessdate=2009-03-17 | location=London | first=Richard | last=Alleyne}}</ref><ref name=NS>{{cite web |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn16785-fossil-of-ultimate-predator-unearthed-in-arctic.html |author = Coghlan, Andy | title=Fossil of 'ultimate predator' unearthed in Arctic |publisher=''[[New Scientist]]'' |date=2009-03-17 |accessdate=2009-03-17}}</ref> However, in 2002, a team of paleontologists in [[Mexico]] discovered the remains of a pliosaur nicknamed as ''Monster of Aramberri'', which is also estimated at {{cvt|15|m|0}} in length.<ref name="GPP">{{cite journal| doi = 10.2113/174.3.271| last1 = Buchy | first1 = M.-C. | last2 = Frey | first2 = E. | last3 = Stinnesbeck | first3 = W. | last4 = López-Oliva | first4 = J.G. | year = 2003 | title = First occurrence of a gigantic pliosaurid plesiosaur in the late Jurassic (Kimmeridgian) of Mexico | url = | journal = Bulletin de la Société Géologique de France | volume = 174 | issue = 3| pages = 271–278}}</ref> This species is, however, claimed to be a juvenile and has been attacked by a larger pliosaur.<ref name="MA">{{Cite web|title=Monster von Arramberri|url=http://www.smnk.de/SMNK/02-Forsch-I/02-03-Geo-Pal/2-3-2-1/2-3-2-1-Inhalt.html|accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref> Some media sources claimed that ''Monster of Aramberri'' was a ''[[Liopleurodon]]'' but its species is unconfirmed thus far.<ref name="GPP" /> Another very large pliosaur was ''[[Pliosaurus|Pliosaurus macromerus]]'', known from a single {{convert|2.8|m|ft|adj=mid|-long}} incomplete mandible. It may have reached {{cvt|18|m|0}}, assuming the skull was about 17% of the total body length.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Cumnor monster mandible|url=http://scienceblogs.com/tetrapodzoology/2007/12/cumnor_monster_mandible.php|accessdate=31 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011174114/http://scienceblogs.com/tetrapodzoology/2007/12/cumnor_monster_mandible.php|archivedate=11 October 2011|df=}}</ref>
==== Ichthyosaurs ([[Ichthyosauria]]) ==== The largest-known [[ichthyosaur]] was ''[[Shastasaurus sikanniensis]]'' at {{cvt|21|m|0}} in length.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Triassic Giant|url=http://www.tyrrellmuseum.com/exhibits/triassic_giant.htm|accessdate=7 February 2010}}</ref> In April 2018, paleontologists announced the discovery of a previously unknown ichthyosaur that may have reached lengths of 26 m (85 ft)- 30 m (100 feet long) making it one of the largest animals known, rivaling the Blue Whale in size. Another giant Ichthyosaur was found as well and it was larger than Lilstock Monster, possibly surpassing Blue Whale in size.<ref>http://www.newsweek.com/giant-ichthyosaur-205-million-year-old-jawbone-discovered-one-largest-animals-877542?yptr=yaho</ref>
==== Turtles and tortoises ([[Testudines]]) ==== * The largest-known turtle ever was ''[[Archelon ischyros]]'' at {{cvt|4|m}} long, {{cvt|4.9|m}} wide and {{cvt|2200|kg}}. The next largest was ''[[Protostega]]'' at {{cvt|3|m}}.<ref name="Lutz1996">{{cite book| last =Lutz| first =Peter L. | authorlink =Peter Lutz |author2=John A. Musick | title =The Biology of Sea Turtles | publisher =CRC Press | year =1996 | location = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=fhm2yGTBiN8C&dq=protostegidae | doi = | isbn =0-8493-8422-2| page =432pp.}}</ref> The second largest seems to be ''[[Stupendemys]]'', with an estimated total carapace length of more than {{cvt|3.3|m}} and weight of up to {{cvt|1814|–|2268|kg}}.<ref>[http://animals.jrank.org/pages/3601/Afro-American-River-Turtles-Podocnemididae-BEHAVIOR-REPRODUCTION.html Afro-American River Turtles: Podocnemididae – Behavior And Reproduction]. animals.jrank.org</ref> ''[[Carbonemys cofrinii]]'' has a shell that measures about {{cvt|1.72|m}} and was estimated to weigh {{cvt|916|kg}}.<ref>[http://phys.org/news/2012-05-reveal-ancient-giant-turtle-fossil.html Researchers reveal ancient giant turtle fossil]. Phys.org (2012-05-17)</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Maugh II|first=Thomas H.|title=Researchers find fossil of a turtle that was size of a Smart car|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-largest-turtle-20120518,0,6876731.story|work=LA Times|date=2012-05-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/17/turtle-fossil-colombia-carbonems-confrinii-car_n_1524960.html| work=Huffington Post | first=David | last=Freeman | title=Car-Sized Reptile Lived Alongside Titanoboa, Scientists Say | date=2012-05-17}}</ref> * Two [[tortoise]]s share the title of largest-known ever tortoise: ''[[Meiolania]]'' at {{cvt|8|ft|order=flip}} long and well over {{cvt|1|ST|tonne|order=flip}}, and ''[[Colossochelys atlas]]'' at {{cvt|8|to|9|ft|order=flip}}{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}and weighing over {{cvt|0.5|ST|kg|order=flip}}.
====Cotylosaurs ([[Captorhinidae]])==== The heavy built ''Moradisaurus grandis'', with a length of {{cvt|2|m}},<ref>[https://books.google.no/books?id=gUpBDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT139&dq=%22captorhinid+reptile+Moradisaurus+grandis%22&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3ovXQjYDfAhWB2SwKHZpQBq0Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22captorhinid%20reptile%20Moradisaurus%20grandis%22&f=false Carboniferous Giants and Mass Extinction: The Late Paleozoic Ice Age World]</ref> is the largest known captorhinid.<ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4878385/ The ontogenetic transformation of the mesosaurid tarsus: a contribution to the origin of the primitive amniotic astragalus]</ref>
====Pareiasaurs ([[Pareiasauridae]])==== The largest-known is ''[[Scutosaurus]]'', up to {{cvt|3|m}} in length, with bony armor, and a number of spikes decorating its skull.
==== Phytosaurs ([[Phytosauria]]) ==== Some of the largest-known phytosaurs include ''[[Redondasaurus]]'' with a length of 6.4 meters and ''[[Smilosuchus]]'' with a size of 6.8 meters.
==== Pterosaurs ([[Pterosauria]]) ==== * The largest-known pterosaur was ''[[Quetzalcoatlus]] northropi'', at {{cvt|127|kg}} and with a wingspan of {{cvt|12|m}}. Another close contender is ''[[Hatzegopteryx]]'', also with a wingspan of {{cvt|12|m}}. This estimate is based on a skull {{cvt|3|m}} long.<ref name="buffetautetal2002">{{cite journal| doi = 10.1007/s00114-002-0307-1| last1 = Buffetaut | first1 = E. | last2 = Grigorescu | first2 = D. | last3 = Csiki | first3 = Z. | year = 2002 | title = A new giant pterosaur with a robust skull from the latest Cretaceous of Romania | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/w55xf7hvvmwp6t5c/ | journal = Naturwissenschaften | volume = 89 | issue = 4| pages = 180–184 | pmid = 12061403| bibcode = 2002NW.....89..180B }}</ref> * Yet another possible contender for the title is ''[[Tropeognathus]]'', which had a {{convert|9|m|ft|adj=on}} wingspan.
=== Non-avian dinosaurs ([[Dinosauria]]) === [[File:Longest dinosaurs1.png|thumb|right|380px|Size comparison of selected giant [[Sauropoda|sauropod]] dinosaurs]] {{Main|Dinosaur size}}
==== Sauropods ([[Sauropoda]]) ==== * A mega-[[sauropoda|sauropod]], ''[[Maraapunisaurus|Maraapunisaurus fragillimus]]'', is a contender for the largest-known dinosaur in history. It has been estimated at {{cvt|58|m|0}} in length and {{cvt|122400|kg}} in weight.<ref name="giant sauropod">Carpenter, K. (2006). "Biggest of the big: a critical re-evaluation of the mega-sauropod ''Amphicoelias fragillimus''." In Foster, J.R. and Lucas, S.G., eds., 2006, ''Paleontology and Geology of the Upper Jurassic Morrison Formation.'' New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science Bulletin '''36''': 131–138.</ref> Unfortunately, the fossil remains of this dinosaur have been lost.<ref name="giant sauropod" /> More recently, it was estimated at {{Cvt|30.3-32|m|ft}} in length.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-10-19|title=Maraapunisaurus fragillimus, N.G. (formerly Amphicoelias fragillimus), a basal Rebbachisaurid from the Morrison Formation (Upper Jurassic) of Colorado|url=https://www.utahgeology.org/publication/maraapunisaurus-fragillimus-n-g-formerly-amphicoelias-fragillimus-a-basal-rebbachisaurid-from-the-morrison-formation-upper-jurassic-of-colorado/|journal=Geology of the Intermountain West|language=en-US|volume=5|issue=9|issn=2380-7601}}</ref> * ''[[Barosaurus lentus]]'' may have been the largest sauropod and largest dinosaur yet discovered. Originally thought to reach only {{cvt|27|m}}, a massive cervical vertebra has been recently attributed to this species, suggesting maximum length of {{cvt|50|m}} and masses of up to {{cvt|100|tonne|ST|0}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://svpow.com/2016/09/16/how-horrifying-was-the-neck-of-barosaurus/|title=How horrifying was the neck of Barosaurus?|date=16 September 2016|website=svpow.com}}</ref> * Other huge sauropods include ''[[Argentinosaurus]]'', ''[[Alamosaurus]]'', and ''[[Puertasaurus]]'' with estimated lengths of {{cvt|30|-|33|m}} and weights of {{cvt|50|-|80|tonne|ST|0}}.<ref>Paul, G.S., 2010, The Princeton Field Guide to Dinosaurs, Princeton University Press.</ref> ''[[Patagotitan]]'' was estimated at {{Cvt|37|m|ft}} in length and {{Cvt|69|tonne|ST}} in mass<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-40889321|title=Giant dinosaur slims down... a bit|date=2017-08-10|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-GB}}</ref>, and was similar in size to ''Argentinosaurus'' and ''Puertasaurus''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://svpow.com/2017/08/09/dont-believe-the-hype-patagotitan-was-not-bigger-than-argentinosaurus/|title=Don’t believe the hype: Patagotitan was not bigger than Argentinosaurus|date=2017-08-09|work=Sauropod Vertebra Picture of the Week|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-US}}</ref> Giant sauropods like ''[[Supersaurus]]'', ''[[Sauroposeidon]]'', and ''[[Diplodocus]]'' probably rivaled them in length but not weight.<ref name="giant sauropod" />
Many large sauropods are still unnamed and may rival the current record holders. * The "Archbishop", a large brachiosaur that was discovered in 1930. The animal was reported to get a scientific paper published by the end of 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://svpow.com/2015/09/03/just-write-the-archbishop-description-already/|title=Just write the Archbishop description already!|date=3 September 2015|website=svpow.com}}</ref> * "Brachiosaurus" ''nougaredi'', is yet another large brachiosaur from Early Cretaceous North Africa. The remains have been lost, but the sacrum drawing remains. They suggest a sacrum of almost {{cvt|5|ft|0}} long, making it the largest dinosaur sacrum discovered so far. * In 2010, the femur of a large sauropod was discovered in France. The femur suggests an animal that grew to immense sizes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paleoking.blogspot.com/2014/07/is-french-monster-euhelopodid.html|title=Is the French Monster a Euhelopodid?|first=|last=Nima|website=paleoking.blogspot.com}}</ref>
==== Non-avian theropods ([[Theropoda]]) ==== [[File:Largest_Theropods.svg|thumb|right|220px|Size comparison of selected giant [[Theropoda|theropod]] dinosaurs]]
* The largest [[Theropoda|theropod]] as well as the largest terrestrial (or possibly semi-aquatic)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/meet-mighty-spinosaurus-first-swimming-dinosaur-180952679/|title=Meet the Mighty Spinosaurus, the First Dinosaur Adapted for Swimming|last=Thompson|first=Helen|work=Smithsonian|access-date=2017-11-22|language=en}}</ref> predator yet known is ''[[Spinosaurus|Spinosaurus aegyptiacus]]'', with the largest specimen known estimated at {{cvt|12.6|-|18|m}} in length and around {{cvt|7|-|20.9|tonne|ST|0}} in weight.<ref name=TH07>{{cite journal|last=Therrien |first=F. |author2=Henderson, D.M. |year=2007 |title=My theropod is bigger than yours...or not: estimating body size from skull length in theropods |journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=108–115 |doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2007)27[108:MTIBTY]2.0.CO;2 |issn=0272-4634}}</ref><ref name=Spino>{{cite journal|last=dal Sasso |first=C. |author2=Maganuco, S. |author3=Buffetaut, E. |author4= Mendez, M.A. |year=2005 |title=New information on the skull of the enigmatic theropod ''Spinosaurus'', with remarks on its sizes and affinities |journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology |volume=25 |issue=4 |pages=888–896|url=http://www.bioone.org/perlserv/?request=get-abstract&doi=10.1671%2F0272-4634%282005%29025%5B0888%3ANIOTSO%5D2.0.CO%3B2|doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2005)025[0888:NIOTSO]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> * Other large theropods were ''[[Giganotosaurus carolinii]]'', and ''[[Tyrannosaurus rex]]'', whose largest specimens known estimated at {{cvt|13.2|m|0}}<ref>{{Cite journal| last = Calvo| first = Jorge O.| last2 = Coria| first2 = Rodolfo| title = New specimen of Giganotosaurus Carolinii| journal = GAIA| pages = 117–122| year = 1998| url = http://www.mnhn.ul.pt/geologia/gaia/7.pdf| postscript = <!--None-->| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080216074438/http://www.mnhn.ul.pt/geologia/gaia/7.pdf| archivedate = 2008-02-16| df = }}</ref> and {{cvt|12.3|m|0}}<ref name=henderson1999>{{Cite journal|author=Henderson DM|date= January 1, 1999|title=Estimating the masses and centers of mass of extinct animals by 3-D mathematical slicing |journal=Paleobiology |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=88–106 |url=http://paleobiol.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/25/1/88}}</ref> in length, respectively. Some other notable giant theropods (e.g. ''[[Carcharodontosaurus]]'','' [[Acrocanthosaurus]]'', and ''[[Mapusaurus]]'') may also have rivaled them in size.
==== Armoured dinosaurs ([[Thyreophora]]) ==== The largest-known [[thyreophoran]] was ''[[Ankylosaurus]]'' at {{cvt|9|m|0}} in length and {{cvt|6|tonne|ST}} in weight.<ref name="vickaryousetal2004">Vickaryous, M.K., [[Teresa Maryańska|Maryanska, T.]], & Weishampel, D.B. 2004. Ankylosauria. In: Weishampel, D.B., Dodson, P., & Osmólska, H. (Eds.). ''The Dinosauria'' (2nd edition). Berkeley: University of California Press. Pp. 363-392.</ref><ref name="coombs">{{cite journal|last=Coombs |first=Walter P.|title=Theoretical Aspects of Cursorial Adaptations in Dinosaurs |journal=[[The Quarterly Review of Biology]] |volume=53 |date=December 1978 |pages=393–418 |doi=10.1086/410790 |issue=4}}</ref> ''[[Stegosaurus]]'' was also {{cvt|9|m}} long but around {{cvt|5|tonne|ST}} tonnes in weight.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}
==== Ceratopsians ([[Ceratopsia]]) ==== The largest [[ceratopsian]] known is ''[[Triceratops|Triceratops horridus]]'', along with the closely related ''[[Eotriceratops|Eotriceratops xerinsularis]]'' both with estimated lengths of {{cvt|9|m|0}}. Ojoceratops and several other ceratopsians rival them in size.<ref>{{cite book| last = Holtz| first = Thomas R. Jr.| title = [[Dinosaurs: The Most Complete, Up-to-Date Encyclopedia for Dinosaur Lovers of All Ages]]| publisher = Random House| year = 2008| location = New York| pages = 52, [http://www.geol.umd.edu/~tholtz/dinoappendix/DinoappendixSummer2008.pdf updated appendix]| isbn = 0-375-82419-7}}</ref>
==== Ornithopods ([[Ornithopoda]]) ==== The very largest-known ornithopods, like ''[[Shantungosaurus]]'' were as heavy as medium-sized sauropods at up to {{cvt|23|tonne|ST}}<ref name="ZM" /><ref name="LL">{{cite journal|last=Morris|first=William J.|year=1981 |title=A new species of hadrosaurian dinosaur from the Upper Cretaceous of Baja California: ?''Lambeosaurus laticaudus''|journal=Journal of Paleontology|volume=55|issue=2|pages=453–462}}</ref>, and {{cvt|16.5|m|0}} in length.<ref name="ZM">{{cite journal|last=Zhao|first=X.|author2=Li, D. |author3=Han, G. |author4=Hao, H. |author5=Liu, F. |author6=Li, L. |author7= Fang, X. |year=2007 |title=''Zhuchengosaurus maximus'' from Shandong Province|journal=Acta Geoscientia Sinica|volume=28|issue=2 |pages=111–122 |doi=10.1007/s10114-005-0808-x}}</ref>
=== Birds ([[Aves]]) === [[File:Aepyornis maximus.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Aepyornis]]'']]
The largest-known birds of all time might have been the [[elephant birds]] of [[Madagascar]]. Of almost the same size was the Australian ''[[Dromornis stirtoni]]''. Both were about {{cvt|3|m}} tall. The elephant birds were up to {{cvt|400|kg}} and ''Dromornis stirtoni'' was up to {{cvt|500|kg}} in weight. The tallest bird ever was the [[giant moa]] (''Dinornis maximus'') at {{cvt|3.6|m}} tall.
The largest-known flight-capable bird was ''[[Argentavis magnificens]]'' which a wingspan of {{cvt|8.3|m}}, and a body weight of {{cvt|110|kg}}.
==== Waterfowl ([[Anseriformes]]) ==== The largest-known waterfowl of all time belonged to the [[Dromornithidae]] (e.g. ''[[Dromornis stirtoni]]'').<ref>{{cite web|title=Dromornis stirtoni |url=http://australianmuseum.com/Dromornis-stirtoni|publisher=Australian Museum}}</ref>
==== Storks and allies ([[Ciconiiformes]]) ==== The largest-known of Ciconiiformes was ''[[Leptoptilos robustus]]'', standing {{cvt|1.8|m}} tall and weighing an estimated {{cvt|16|kg}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/earth/hi/earth_news/newsid_9261000/9261713.stm|title=Giant bird found on hobbit island|date=7 December 2010|publisher=|via=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=A new species of giant marabou stork (Aves: Ciconiiformes) from the Pleistocene of Liang Bua, Flores (Indonesia)|vauthors=Meijer HJ, ((R ADue))|journal= Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society| year=2010|volume=160| pages=707–724| doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.2010.00616.x}}</ref>
==== Hesperornithines ([[Hesperornithes]]) ==== The largest-known of the hesperornithines was ''[[Canadaga arctica]]'' at {{cvt|5|ft|order=flip}} long.
==== Diatrymas ([[Gastornithiformes]]) ==== The largest-known [[diatryma]] was ''[[Gastornis]]'' {{cvt|1.75|m}} tall, with large individuals up to {{cvt|2|m}} tall.
==== Teratorns ([[Teratornithidae]]) ==== The largest-known teratorn and the largest flying bird ever was ''[[Argentavis]]''. The immense bird had a wingspan estimated up to {{cvt|8.3|m}} and a weight up to {{cvt|110|kg}}. It was as high as an adult human when standing.
==== Phorusrhacids ([[Phorusrhacidae]]) ==== The largest-known-ever gruiform and largest phorusrhacid or "terror bird" (highly predatory, flightless birds of South America) was ''[[Brontornis]]'', which was about {{cvt|175|cm}} tall at the shoulder, could raise its head {{cvt|2.8| m}} above the ground and could have weighed as much as {{cvt|400|kg}}.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Systematic revision of the Phorusrhacidae (Aves: Ralliformes) |doi=10.1590/S0031-10492003000400001 |journal=Papéis Avulsos de Zoologia |volume=43 |issue=4 |year=2003 |first1=Herculano M.F. |last1=Alvarenga |first2=Elizabeth |last2=Höfling}}</ref> The immense phorushacid ''[[Kelenken]]'' stood {{cvt|3|-|3.2|m}} tall with a skull {{cvt|28|in|order=flip}} long ({{cvt|18|in|order=flip|disp=sqbr}} of which was beak), had the largest head of any known bird. The largest North American phorusrhacid is ''[[Titanis]]'', which is about {{cvt|2.5|m}} tall, as tall as a forest elephant.
==== Accipitriforms ([[Accipitriformes]]) ==== The largest-known bird of prey ever was the enormous [[Haast's eagle]] (''Harpagornis moorei''), with a wingspan of {{cvt|2.6|to|3|m}}, relatively short for their size. Total length was probably up to {{cvt|1.4|m}} in female and they weighed about {{cvt|10|to|15|kg}}. The largest extinct ''[[Titanohierax]]'' was a giant hawk about 8 kilograms that lived in the Antilles, where it was among the top predators. [[File:Giant Haasts eagle attacking New Zealand moa.jpg|thumb|right|[[Haast's eagle]], the largest bird of prey, attacking [[moa]]]]
==== Gamebirds ([[Galliformes]]) ==== The largest-known in this group was a giant flightless ''[[Sylviornis]]'', a bird {{cvt|1.70|m}} long and weighing up to about {{cvt|30|kg}}.
==== Songbirds ([[Passeriformes]]) ==== The largest-known songbird is the extinct [[giant grosbeak]] (''Chloridops regiskongi'') at {{cvt|11|in|order=flip}} long.
==== Cormorants and allies ([[Pelecaniformes]]) ==== The largest-known cormorant was the [[spectacled cormorant]] of the North Pacific (''Phalacrocorax perspicillatus''), which became extinct around 1850, was larger still, averaging around {{cvt|6.4|kg}} and {{cvt|1.15|m}}.<ref>[http://www.calacademy.org/exhibits/science_under_sail/biodiversity.html California Academy of Sciences – Science Under Sail] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607150621/http://www.calacademy.org/exhibits/science_under_sail/biodiversity.html |date=2012-06-07 }}. Calacademy.org</ref>
==== Bony-toothed birds ([[Odontopterygiformes]]) ==== The largest-known in this group—which has been variously allied with Procellariiformes, Pelecaniformes and Anseriformes—and the largest flying birds of all time other than ''Argentavis'' were the huge ''[[Pelagornis]]'', ''[[Cyphornis]]'', ''[[Dasornis]]'', ''[[Gigantornis]]'' and ''[[Osteodontornis]]''. They had a wingspan of {{cvt|5.5|–|6|m}} and stood about {{cvt|1.2|m}} tall. Exact size estimates and judging which one was largest are not yet possible for these birds, as their bones were extremely thin-walled, light and fragile, and thus most are only known from very incomplete remains.
==== Woodpeckers and allies ([[Piciformes]]) ==== The largest-known woodpecker is the possibly extinct [[imperial woodpecker]] (''Campephilus imperialis'') with a total length of about {{cvt|22|in|order=flip}}. The largest woodpecker confirmed to be extant is the [[great slaty woodpecker]] (''Mulleripicus pulverulentus'').
==== Parrots ([[Psittaciformes]]) ==== The largest-known parrot is the extinct [[Norfolk Island kaka]] (''Nestor productus''), about {{cvt|38|cm}} long.
==== Penguins ([[Sphenisciformes]]) ==== The largest-known penguin of all time was ''[[Anthropornis nordenskjoeldi]]'' of [[New Zealand]] and [[Antarctica]]. It stood {{cvt|1.7|m|ftin}} in height and was {{cvt|90|kg}} in weight. Similar in size were the [[New Zealand giant penguin]] (''Pachydyptes pondeorsus'') with a height of {{cvt|1.4|to|1.6|m}} and weighing possibly around {{cvt|80|to|100|kg}} and over, and ''[[Icadyptes salasi]]'' at {{cvt|1.5|m}} tall.
==== Owls ([[Strigiformes]]) ==== The largest-known owl of all time was the [[Cuba]]n ''[[Ornimegalonyx]]'' at {{cvt|43.3|in|order=flip}} tall probably exceeding {{cvt|9|kg}}.<ref>Arredondo, Oscar (1976) translated Olson, Storrs L. ''The Great Predatory Birds of the Pleistocene of Cuba'' pp. 169-187 in "Smithsonian Contributions to Paleobiology number 27; Collected Papers in Avian Paleontology Honoring the 90th Birthday of Alexander Wetmore"</ref>
=== Amphibians ([[Amphibia]]) === [[File:Beelzebufo BW.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Beelzebufo ampinga]]'']]
The largest-known amphibian of all time was the {{cvt|30|ft|order=flip}} long [[temnospondyli]] ''[[Prionosuchus]]''. Another huge temnospondyli was ''[[Koolasuchus]]'' at {{cvt|16|ft|order=flip}} long, but only {{cvt|1|ft|order=flip}} high.
==== Frogs ([[Frog|Anura]]) ==== The largest-known frog ever was a yet unnamed species frog that was about {{convert|58|-|59|cm|in|1|adj=mid|-long}}.<ref>Evidence of a giant helmeted frog (Australobatrachia, Calyptocephalellidae) from Eocene levels of the Magallanes Basin, southernmost Chile</ref>
==== Diadectomorpha ==== The largest-known diacectid, ''[[Diadectes]]'', was a heavily built animal, {{cvt|1.5|to|3|m}} long, with thick vertebrae and ribs.
==== Anthracosauria ==== The largest-known anthracosaur was ''[[Anthracosaurus]]'', a predator. It could reach up to {{cvt|12|ft|order=flip}} in length. ''[[Eogyrinus]]'' commonly reached {{cvt|4.6|m}}; however, it was more lightly built.<ref name=EoDP>{{cite book|editor=Palmer, D.|year=1999|title= The Marshall Illustrated Encyclopedia of Dinosaurs and Prehistoric Animals|publisher= Marshall Editions|location=London|page= 53|isbn= 1-84028-152-9}}</ref>
==== Temnospondyli ==== The largest-known temnospondyl amphibian is ''[[Prionosuchus]]'', which grew to lengths of {{cvt|9|m}}.<ref>Levy, D.L., & Heald, R. (2015). "Biological Scaling Problems and Solutions in Amphibians." Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Biology, a019166.</ref>
=== Lobe-finned fish ([[Sarcopterygii]]) === The largest-known of these was the {{cvt|6|-|7|m}} long ''[[Rhizodus]]''.
=== Ray-finned fish ([[Actinopterygii]]) === The largest-known bony fish of all time was the [[pachycormid]], ''[[Leedsichthys problematicus]]'', at around {{cvt|16.5|m}} long.<ref name="Liston2013">Liston, J., Newbrey, M., Challands, T., and Adams, C., 2013, "Growth, age and size of the Jurassic pachycormid ''Leedsichthys problematicus'' (Osteichthyes: Actinopterygii) in: Arratia, G., Schultze, H. and Wilson, M. (eds.) ''Mesozoic Fishes 5 – Global Diversity and Evolution''. Verlag Dr. Friedrich Pfeil, München, Germany, pp. 145-175</ref> Claims of larger individuals persist.
==== Ichthyodectiformes ([[Ichthyodectiformes]]) ==== The largest-known of [[ichthyodectiform]] fish was ''[[Xiphactinus]]'', which measured {{cvt|6.0|m|0}} long.
=== Cartilaginous fish ([[Chondrichthyes]]) === [[File:Megalodon scale.svg|thumb|''[[Megalodon]]'' (grey/red) with the [[whale shark]] (purple), [[great white shark]] (green), and [[human]] (black) for scale]]
==== Mackerel sharks ([[Lamniformes]]) ==== An extinct megatoothed [[shark]], [[Megalodon|''C. megalodon'']] is by far the biggest shark known.<ref>{{cite video|people=deGruy, Michael|title=Perfect Shark|medium=TV-Series|publisher=BBC (UK)|date=2006}}</ref> This giant shark reached a total length of more than {{cvt|16|m}}.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Klimley|first1=Peter|last2=Ainley|first2=David|title=Great White Sharks: The Biology of Carcharodon carcharias|publisher=Academic Press|year=1996|isbn=0-12-415031-4}}{{page needed|date=July 2014}}</ref><ref name="AN">{{cite journal|vauthors=Pimiento C, Ehret DJ, Macfadden BJ, Hubbell G |title=Ancient nursery area for the extinct giant shark megalodon from the Miocene of Panama |journal=PLOS ONE |volume=5 |issue=5 |pages=e10552 |year=2010 |pmid=20479893 |pmc=2866656 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0010552|bibcode=2010PLoSO...510552P }}</ref> ''C. megalodon'' may have approached a maximum of {{cvt|20.3|m}} in total length and {{cvt|103|tonne|ST|0}} in mass.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wroe|first=S.|author2=Huber, D. R. |author3=Lowry, M. |author4=McHenry, C. |author5=Moreno, K. |author6=Clausen, P. |author7=Ferrara, T. L. |author8=Cunningham, E. |author9=Dean, M. N. |author10= Summers, A. P. |title=Three-dimensional computer analysis of white shark jaw mechanics: how hard can a great white bite?|volume=276|issue=4|pages=336–342|year= 2008|doi=10.1111/j.1469-7998.2008.00494.x|journal=Journal of Zoology}}</ref>
==== Symmoriid ([[Symmoriida]]) ==== The largest-known symmoriid was ''[[Stethacanthus]]'' at {{cvt|2|m}} long.
==== Eugenedont ([[Eugeneodontida]]) ==== The largest-known eugenedont is a yet unnamed species of ''[[Helicoprion]]'' discovered in Idaho. The specimens suggest an animal that possibly exceeded {{cvt|12|m}} in length.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eartharchives.org/articles/buzzsaw-toothed-leviathans-cruised-the-ancient-seas/|title=Buzzsaw-toothed leviathans cruised the ancient seas|website=eartharchives.org}}</ref>
Another fairly large eugenedont is Parahelicoprion. The specimens suggest an animal that grew to the same size ({{cvt|12|m|ft|disp=sqbr}}), but was much less slender and overall less heavy.<ref>http://img06.deviantart.net/8207/i/2015/143/8/e/parahelicoprion_clerci_by_teratophoneus-d8uf4rh.png</ref>
==== Hybodontiform ([[Hybodontiformes]]) ==== The largest-known hydontiformid is ''[[Ptychodus]]'', which was about {{cvt|32|ft|order=flip}} long.
=== Placoderms ([[Placodermi]]) === The largest-known [[placoderm]] was the {{cvt|6|m}} long ''[[Dunkleosteus]]''. It is estimated to have weighed around {{cvt|3.6|tonne|ST}}. Its relative, ''[[Titanichthys]]'', may have rivaled it in size.
== Arthropods ([[Arthropoda]]) ==
=== [[Dinocaridida]] ===
==== Radiodont ([[Radiodonta]]) ==== The largest-known is ''[[Aegirocassis]]'' at least {{cvt|7|ft|order=flip}} long.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2015/03/11/us-science-creature-idINKBN0M725O20150311|title=Gigantic ancient arthropod was really 'a very peaceful guy'|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|website=reuters.com}}</ref>
=== [[Chelicerata]] ===
==== Eurypterids ([[Eurypterida]]) ==== The largest-known in this group was ''[[Jaekelopterus rhenaniae]]'' at {{cvt|2.5|m}} in length. A close contender was ''[[Pterygotus]]'' at {{cvt|2.3|m}} in length.
==== Arachnids ([[Arachnida]]) ==== There are two contenders for largest-known ever [[arachnid]]: ''[[Pulmonoscorpius kirktonensis]]'' and ''[[Brontoscorpio|Brontoscorpio anglicus]]''. Pulmonoscorpius was {{cvt|70|cm}} Brontoscorpio was {{cvt|90|cm}}. The biggest difference is that ''Brontoscorpio'' was aquatic, and ''Pulmonoscorpius'' was terrestrial. ''Brontoscorpio'' is not to be confused with various [[Eurypterids]]: it was a true scorpion with a venomous stinger.
=== [[Myriapoda]] === The largest-known myriapod by far was the giant ''[[Arthropleura]]''. Measuring {{cvt|2.5|m}} and {{cvt|45|cm}} wide, it was the largest-known terrestrial [[arthropod]] of all time. Like its modern-day relatives, Arthropleura would have likely sprayed hydrogen cyanide at potential predators, although its sheer size and tough exoskeleton protected it from attack.
=== Trilobitomorpha ===
==== Trilobites ([[Trilobita]]) ==== Some of these extinct marine arthropods exceeded {{cvt|60|cm}} in length. A nearly complete specimen of ''[[Isotelus|Isotelus rex]]'' from [[Manitoba]] attained a length over {{cvt|70|cm}}, and an ''[[Ogyginus forteyi]]'' from Portugal was almost as long. Fragments of trilobites suggest even larger record sizes. An isolated [[pygidium]] of ''[[Hungioides bohemicus]]'' implies that the full animal was {{cvt|90|cm}} long.<ref name="Hungioides">{{Cite journal| last1 = Gutiérrez-Marco| first1 = Juan C. | last2 = Sá | first2 = Artur A. | last3 = Garcia-Bellido | first3 = Diego C. | last4 = Rabano | first4 = Isabel | last5 = Valério | first5 = Manuel | title = Giant Trilobites and Trilobite Clusters from the Ordovician of Portugal | journal = Geology | volume = 37 | pages = 443–446 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1130/G25513A.1| bibcode = 2009Geo....37..443G }}</ref>
=== Insects ([[Insecta]]) ===
==== Sawflies, wasps, bees, ants and allies ([[Hymenoptera]]) ==== The largest-known of this group was the giant ant ''[[Titanomyrma|Titanomyrma giganteum]]'' at {{cvt|3|cm}}, with [[Eusociality|queens]] growing to {{cvt|6|cm}}. It had a wingspan of {{cvt|15|cm}}.<ref name="Messel">{{cite journal|title=Messel|author=Schaal, Stephan|date=27 January 2006|work=|publisher=|doi=10.1038/npg.els.0004143|journal=eLS}}</ref>
==== Protodonata ==== The largest-known in this group was probably ''[[Meganeura]]'' with a wingspan of {{cvt|75|cm}}.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Biomarker Guide: Biomarkers and Isotopes in Petroleum Systems and Earth History |work=Google Books |date= 2005 |page=1107 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qk8anEDZykwC&pg=PA731&lpg=PA731&dq=meganeura+75+cm&source=bl&ots=EV-f6TwRxZ&sig=JQy_hAaI37ZyC0UMh69AcKv-bIA&hl=hu&sa=X&ei=qRKVVe_XAqPjywO_7I_wBA&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBjg8#v=onepage&q=meganeura%2075%20cm&f=false}}</ref> Another enormous and possibly larger species was ''[[Meganeuropsis permiana]]''.
==== Siphonaptera ==== The largest-known in this group was probably ''[[Saurophthirus]]'', growing to {{cvt|1|in|order=flip}} in length. It possibly sucked the [[blood]] of [[pterosaur]]s.
==== Palaeodictyoptera ==== The largest-known insect of this order was ''[[Mazothairos]]'', with a wingspan of up to {{cvt|22|in|order=flip}}.
== Molluscs ([[Mollusca]]) == [[File:Campanile giganteum.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Campanile giganteum]]'' shell]]
=== Gastropods ([[Gastropoda]]) ===
==== Snails and slugs ([[Gastropoda]]) ==== The largest-known of this group were in the genus ''[[Campanile (gastropod)|Campanile]]'', with the extinct ''[[Campanile giganteum]]'' having shell lengths up to {{cvt|90|cm}}.<ref>http://www.e-periodica.ch/cntmng?pid=egh-001:1987:80::1248</ref>
=== Bivalves ([[Bivalvia]]) ===
==== Bivalves ([[Bivalvia]]) ==== The largest-known [[bivalve]] ever was ''[[Platyceramus platinus]]'', a giant that usually had an axial length of {{cvt|1|m}}, but some individuals could reach an axial length of up to {{cvt|3|m}}.
=== Cephalopods ([[Cephalopoda]]) === {{Main|Cephalopod size}} [[File:Parapuzosia seppenradensis cast.jpg|thumb|''[[Parapuzosia seppenradensis]]'' shell]]
==== Ammonites ([[Ammonoidea]]) ==== The largest-known ammonite was ''[[Parapuzosia seppenradensis]]''. A partial fossil specimen found in [[Germany]] had a shell diameter of {{cvt|1.95|m}}, but the [[living chamber]] was incomplete, so the estimated shell diameter was probably about {{cvt|2.55|m}} when it was alive.
==== Belemnites ([[Belemnoidea]]) ==== The largest-known belemnite was ''[[Megateuthis gigantea]]'' with a guard of {{cvt|46|cm}} in length and an estimated total length {{cvt|3|m}} long.
==== Nautiloids ([[Nautiloidea]]) ==== The longest- and largest-known of this group was ''[[Cameroceras]]'' with a shell length of {{cvt|9|m}}.<ref name="TandK">{{cite journal|author1=Teichert C|author2=B Kummel |year= 1960|title=Size of Endocerid Cephalopods|journal=Breviora Mus. Comp. Zool.|volume=128|pages=1–7}}</ref>
==== Neocoleoidea ==== Both ''[[Tusoteuthis]]'' and ''[[Yezoteuthis]]'' are estimated to be similar in size to the modern-day [[giant squid]].<ref>http://www.tonmo.com/science/fossils/cretaceousGS.php{{full citation needed|date=July 2014}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Dinosaur size]] * [[Largest organisms]] * [[Megafauna]] * [[Template:Nature timeline|Nature timeline]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Largest Prehistoric Organisms}} [[Category:Articles with inconsistent citation formats]] [[Category:Lists of prehistoric animals]] [[Category:Lists of largest animals]]
